												Sit down, son. You just stumbled upon the page of the best shooter ever made. Pay some respect. Before the days of shooters that holds your hand and aim for you, that regenerate your health and show you what to do like a baby, there was this. Unreal Tournament 2004 - the most brutal, adrenalin-fueled shooter since Quake 3 Arena, a game so fast-paced its guaranteed you'll burn your eyes from not blinking for so long. They say we only use 20% of our brains - well, if you play this game on the hardest difficulty, you'll be using 100% i assure you. Holy hell son, this game uses so much of your brain it pretty much even cures autism. This game is filled with so much testosterone you have to shave your beard every forty minutes of gametime.Gameplay wise, this game is delicious. With an amazing arsenal of creative, varied and badass weapons, its certified there is a gun for everyone and every situation - sniper rifles that shoot lightning bolts, a triple rocket launcher, jesus christ did i mention a shotgun that shoots grenades too? (The Flak Cannon, considered the number 1 best gun of all times by PC Gamer). Also, with the ability of limitless dodging, walljumping and even double-jumping, the potential for amazing acrobatic moves to evade your enemy's attacks are so great not even Dante from Devil May Cry can keep up. Yep: he cries every night because he cant be as badass as you, when you're playing this game. But this is the bare basic - to survive in the Online arenas, you better be backflipping over your enemies and giving them an instagib headshot while upside down. That's how you play this. However, to be good you have to have absolute keyboard coordination and aiming abilities - it aint easy to do those moves while scoring headshots airborne. Its so hardcore, they say ninjas have to play this game to graduate in Ninja School as their last test. I'm not even kidding. The maps are varied, from skyscrapers reaching space and low-grav to gothic dungeons, futuristic egyptian pyramids to spaceships blasting in hyperspace - there are over 140 maps in this game (thats almost 5 times more than any CoD), ranging from Deathmatch maps to Capture the Flag, Double Domination, Onslaught (Battlefield-esque map node domination), Assault (from the original UT) and even Bombing Run (Its soccer. WITH GUNS). And kid, that's not even taking into account the thousands of maps released by fans - that's right, the modding community is huge for this game. (No DLC crap, no. You get all those maps and access to mod maps for free. Welcome to oldschool shooters)The soundtrack and graphics certainly do not falter. We get badass tracks like the one in DM-Asbestos, and others have more epic orchestral music (for actual epic scenes: assaulting an alien mothership to save Earth) and the graphics, for their time, were considered to be amazing (Even modern games, like Killing Floor, use this game engine as base). The visual and audio presentation certainly do not lack, but to this day this game isnt known for having pretty trees, its known for being the best shooter of all times and god damn it does it right. Together with the classic Unreal Tournament and Quake 3 Arena, Unreal Tournament 2004 is known by shooter veterans worldwide to be the best competitive shooter experience that ever existed. Think you're ready for that? Take off the Angry Birds shirt, the Casual of Duty cap and get ready for a terrific head-hunting experience with the game that INVENTED Double-Kills, Headshots and Killing-Sprees (that all games rip-off nowadays).Final Score: 10/10

												This is THE game that got me into gaming, I was 9 when I started playing it in 2004 and I still come back every now and then to play some good 'ol Unreal.Almost every game-mode is fun and well designed, they range from regular old Deathmatch to Capture the Flag with Ion-Canon tanks and Jeeps with blades on them, invasion was always my favorite, it was so well designed in fact that games like Killing Floor were born from it.The weapons are also a blast to use, PC Gamer even crowned Unreal's 'Flak Cannon' the best gun in PC gaming, but it doesn't end there, the are plasma and laser guns to mess around with, but you also have your trusty old rocket launcher and even a steerable mini-nuke. If you don't like messing around with such a huge arsenal you can play with an Instagib instead, which is a slow-firing weapon with 100% accuracy that instantly kills (and gibs, as the name suggests) anything you hit with it.Another thing that made it so vastly different from all the boring arena shooters we have nowadays was the crazy mobility, you could do double jumps or jump against a wall and then jump from there again, leading to some pretty hectic but awesome gameplay, you could enable a handy little device called the Translocator that allowed you to shoot a disc and teleport to it with a simple click, making camping virtually impossible.The game has tons of maps from itself, but Unreal has a very lively modding community and thus hunderds of maps for every game-mode are available for download, you can also download costum skins and even entirely new weapons, just a shame that the game has no steam-workshop.Even though the game is pretty old by now, there's still a reasonable amount of people playing this gem, if you want to play one of the best sci-fi shooters on the market I'd suggest giving this one a go (And not Unreal Tournament 2007, it didn't live up to the standard of the Unreal franchise in my opinion).

												Many a day of my life was lost playing this game as an early teen. I returned to it now, 7 years later and it still smokes any non-military (meaning not in the vein of CS, Battlefield etc.) competitive shooter out there.As AlexOfSpades put it, "before the days of shooters that holds your hand and aim for you, that regenerate your health and show you what to do like a baby, there was this." Yes indeed. I have gotten so accustomed to these games that, when I bought this game and went straight to my old habit of a warm-up Masterful bot DM, I had my♥♥♥♥♥HANDED TO ME. Time. And Time. Again. Until my rusty inner gaming beast finally tossed away the awful crutches that today's games forced upon it and I once again felt the rush of a full-blown UT deathmatch.This shows what a bunch of wimps today's "fast-paced shooters" are made for. This game requires insane concentration, mental sharpness, quick decision making and finger/fine motorics coordination of a freaking Navy jet pilot. Stand still - dead, wrong weapon for the situation - dead, miss a powerup - dead, let the enemy pick up a health pack - dead, shoddy tactics in team matches - dead. No room for error (providing you have set the difficulty level high enough to actually be challenged). It's a wild ride and there is no better feeling than finally letting go of your poor, burned-out mouse and seeing your username at the top of the scoreboard.Technically, the game excels at everything. The weapons are perfectly balanced, the powerups are perfectly distributed, the gameplay is smooth and uninterrupted. The graphics are 2004 appropriate, but even today, they are a thing of beauty, the colors are clear and it doesn't have the murky, gray/brown "drape" like UT3. The only thing that kind of bugged me was no native widescreen support, but the fix is super easy, no problems there.However, as much as I can gush over the "old days" of adrenaline-fuelled arena bloodshed, it's dated. Not the game itself, as I said, it is arena mayhem at its most perfect, but the concept itself has sadly fallen out of fashion. There will always be devout maniacs such as myself and a lot of people who gave this game a thumbs up, but ultimately, I think there's little hope of this kind of action coming back in this form.Long story short: if you spent days trying to find a tactic to bring down a Power Core in a certain map, or spent days honing your no-scope headshots, get this, and feel the rush. If you're a modern gamer new to this game, get it, take it easy at first, up the difficulty when you feel you have the grasp, and realize that CoD is about as intense as PacMan. If you're expecting to get your mind blown by anything other than a Flak Cannon, don't get this game. This is nothing new. It is something old. And it still kicks gobs of♥♥♥♥♥

The review is written strictly from single-player perspective!Short version: 94%UT2k4 is, with little doubt, the pinnacle of the Unreal franchise with the largest variation in game modes, best maps, biggest arsenal, and one of the best AI opponents of its time.Long version:It took almost four years for Epic to create a sequel to Unreal Tournament, and they were aiming high with a proposed yearly series. Sadly, they started with UT2003, which changed and removed so many things that despite the initial success it flopped hard: so much so that they had to release Unreal Tournament 2004 well ahead schedule. Thankfully they listened to the fans, and not only gave back every removed game element, but created an amalgam of the best features of UT2003 and UT ’99.The action is faster than ever, but not to the point where it is disadvantageous to a new player. Old weapons and map types complement the new ones, offering a variety not just in play style, but in game modes– including a Halo-inspired vehicle-using war scenario.The campaign also received an overhaul. You still need to complete all but one game type to win, but the small changes made sure that each play through can be different: instead of set maps you are given a small pool for each stage. For death match enthusiast 1v1 and team DMs are offered as optional challenges, boosting the possible team management strategies and game time to even higher levels.Some of the game modes like Bombing Run (a cross between Blood Bowl and Counter-Strike) and Double Domination (Domination with camping strategies) weren’t received well, but against bots they can be one of the fastest-paced modes you can play. And even if you dislike them, the other modes and the myriad of high-quality player-made map packs can ensure longevity even after all these years.

Remember when games, back in the days, let you customize your matches/lobbies any way you wanted and included AI bots that are not only smart, but also challenging? Pepperidge farm remembers!Regardless of its age, Unreal Tournament 2004 (a.k.a. UT2004) still remains one of the greatest and most competitive FPS games of all time (along with the other entries in the series). Still works well on modern systems without any tweaking necessary.+ UT2004 is a fast-paced and chaotic game where accuracy and awareness are the main requisite to "frag like it's 1999", also thanks to a wide range of guns that are different from each other and have both primary and secondary firing modes.+ The 2004 edition is an UT game at its core while still adding many new features and gamemodes, for example Onslaught, which gives the game a "Battlefield 2" approach with vehicular combat and nodes to capture on huge maps. The old Assault gamemode from the first game in the series has also been improved thanks to less linear levels and vehicles.+ While the vanilla game has lots of content and variety on its own, the still-active modding community offers so much more (for example, important mods to mention which have then turned into stand-alone games like the wave-based Killing Floor and WW2 shooter Red Orchestra).+ This game is multiplayer-centered. You can host listen servers with port forwarding required if you want to play with friends, or host dedicated ones, but even offline it offers a great experience: bots are human-like, they work on all gamemodes and you can choose from many difficulty options for them, along with more customization options.Well worth the purchase, wether you're an online or offline player!

												My favourite iteration of the UT series.Vanilla UT2004 has more than enough game mods and maps to swallow up huge amounts of your time. The bots cater for every skill level and do a good job of making offline matches fun in their own right. It also has a campaign mode that lets you buy and sell players, challening other clans to matches as you head on up the league table. It was very enjoyable back in the day and I was sad When UT3 didn't have the same sort of campaign.The game will run smoothly on all but the most basic of computers and has been a staple of LAN parties ever since its launch. It has aged brilliantly and was well supported by its community back in the day, making it worth getting for mods like 'Air Buccaneers' alone!Before UT2004 there was a 2003 edition which was very similar. There was outcry when this version was announced, with people accusing it of becoming an annual series, much like EA sport titles. I'm almost sad that that wasn't the case, since this 2004 version contains everything that came with the 2003 edition, doubled the number of maps, added new game modes (including a very popular vehicle mode which is better balanced than I had ever expected it to be) and generally rendered the previous version of the game obsolete.I still haven't scratched the surface of what this game contains. It's big enough that even if you only like a small fraction of what it has to offer, you'll still have more to play with than most entire games have to offer. An odd little side-note, but both girls I've shown this game to have loved it, even though they're not generally fans of aggressive, adrenaline-based frag fests. Odd.It's a thumbs up from me. The only irritating thing about it is that occasionally matches reach a frustrating stalemate, or you begin to lose through no fault of your own which is an incredibly frustrating experience. You'd expect that in online modes but offline, when you're outperforming the bots by a considerable margin, can get very frustrating. I've hardly touched the online part of this game, it's never appealed to me. Call me a noob, but the fact this game still holds my attention should pay adequate testament to the quality of this title. UT2004: 10 games rolled into one. Fun for all the family. 'cept children, probably not suitable for them.

												When it comes to mind-less FPS violence, I can’t believe people would rather play mediocre games such as CoD when they could just go with legendary classics such as this game. I’m a huge fan of this game, I’ve played it for YEARS, I’ve even been on tournaments of this game and even won two of those. However, I’m gonna try to leave that aside and give you a proper review of why you should or not buy this game, and as usual I will start with the negative parts of it. ...Or I would if this game had much negative stuff. Really, the only negative stuff I can think off have to be Assault maps, as they deviate too much from the other game-modes, and vehicle based maps can be a little weird at times. And maybe that it's multiplayer community isn't that full of people after more than 10 years after release. That’s it!Instead, what does this game have that it’s good?First and foremost, the AI. It’s good. It’s really f#cking good. In fact I’m an expert at bugging and breaking games, and rarely I’ve found the AI breaking and falling apart. The game also has the option to put a random difficulty mode and then analyze how well you do against it, then constantly change it so it’s all up to your skill level, something that I don’t think I’ve seen in other games and should be in most of them.Going right up to that are the maps. Not even one of them feels the same as others, only a few of them grow a bit stale because of them being too big or too small and sh#t like that. The game also has maps from previous games that are memorable, such as Facing Worlds, which is the De_Dust of Unreal Tournament, and even adding remakes and different versions of them.Another big-#ss point in favor of the game has to be the soundtrack. I ain’t f#cking arround when I say, IT’S REALLY F#CKING GOOD. The devs knew what they needed to make the action feel even more intense, and succeeded immensely. The gameplay itself is also kind of a master-piece, a one of it’s kind in FPS games. All guns (except the ones to start with) are useful in their own way and have their own flair to themselves. They all have their own ways of being used and are all fun to waste people with, although some need more aim than others, such as the Lightning-Gun/Sniper Rifle and Shock Rifle. And hell, any game that has an Anti-Air weapon turned into a shotgun with a grenade launcher option has to be a great game on paper.Something that’s also rather unique to this kind of game are the sprees, and the game announcer on it’s own. You know how in these modern fps crap games you get rewards for killing multiple people on a single life? Well f#ck that, here instead you get to hear insane voice clips from the announcer not believing how could you just do what to a human being. From the classic “KILLING SPREE!” to the infamous “HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥”, they’re all memorable. Also, the game keeps track of what you do in a match, and hitting F3 will show you information about it, such as how sh#t your aim is or how many sprees you got in that match.All and all, is this game worth it?  Did you even pay any attention? Of course it is. It’s WAY superior to the sequel it got later on, which kinda sucked, and it has really good mod support. Infact, games such as Red Orchestra and Killing Floor started as mods for Unreal Tournament 2004, it’s that good. I seriously recommend it to any FPS fan out there who just wants to chill out and have fun murdering anything that f#cking moves. And if you want, install the Bloddy Hell mod, which makes, between a ton of other crap, blood and gore more sadistic and makes it stay on the map forever if you feel so, which is BLODDY F#CKING GREAT. TL;DR Edition: A classic FPS that never seems to age. F#cking good and cheap. If you like FPS and you don’t have it, you have serious issues either in your brain or your wallet.

IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED VIDEO GAMES, GO GET A LIFE!(BEFORE STARTING OFF : if you are experiencing troubles regarding your screen moving without you touching it, you're going to have to uncheck the following : mouse smoothing, reduce mouse lag and enable joystick. I haven't figured out yet how to play with a controller).All honesty though, this game has come quite the way from it's original conception. Back in the day Unreal was an amazing shooter and still to this day still holds highly to it's acclaim. The mods have helped significantly to keep the game interesting. Unreal Tournament is most likely known for it's obscene commentary, extreme gore, and weapons that aliens look like they developed. Before you start playing multiplayer, there is a campaign available that will get you ready for multiplayer. In UT, you may customize your character from a large select group of races in which each have their own attributes. The guns in this game are absolutely fantastic. They range from basic shotgun and rockets to energy weapons that will vaporize an opponent. I should say the guns are one of the main reasons why this game got so big; the fact they also introduced alternative firing with both the same amount of strength really plays to the shooters advantage. The game play itself compared to other shoots is a little fast as players move throughout the map with speed. Movement/controls is quite basic but includes sprinting, crouching, jumping, lateral movements and double tapping a movement button will make the player roll forward. Like Halo, you won't find many players standing still to take a shot as you are absolutely vulnerable when not in motion. What blew my mind was one map I played online where I was not only able to enjoy the basics the game came with, but some crazy yahoo out there took his time to make vehicles (that resemble warthogs), ghost sort of looking vehicles that can jump vertically up and down, tanks and of course a ship that flies through the air. The mods get pretty crazy and some maps feature fixed guns. Game modes that are available in this game are standard deathMatch, team deathMatch, capture the flag and double domination (which is sort of like King of the Hill). Upon killing a lot of opponents or collecting adrenaline, players can use it for regeneration (Down, Down, Down, Down), invisibility (Right, Right, Left, Left), faster rate of fire (Up, Up, Down, Down) and faster movement speed (Up, Up, Up, Up) - (pint size and berserk are also available but I do not know the proper combos... yet). This adds an extra depth to already an enjoyable game. Picking up more health, armor or even ammo is quite easy and shouldn't be too much of an issue to get the gun you want. It's how much can you dodge while you're getting there. I should also add the maps I've come across so far have been superb.The visuals are as good as they can be for their age and an update to them could make or break the game. It's vintage-ness is what's really appreciated. Sounds are pretty good, although basic and not extremely varied but provide a good context for the gun you're firing. I would absolutely recommend this game on sale to anyone. It is simply a fun FPS that can be enjoyed by anyone. You will quickly see some players that have really taken their time to precise their movements and their shooting patterns.RATING : rock solid 8/10Gameplay B+ Story / Campaign C+ Visuals / User Interface C+ Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B- Overall  B-ScreenShots :  Looks almost nothing like it Using a link gun to disable an air unit

Taking the misteps out of Unreal Tournament 2003 and adding some cool new features paid off in spades for Epic and UT fans.This time around, UT looks dazzling - even in 2017. Deathmath, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, Dominiation, and Assault all make comebacks. Domination has a noticable difference in that teams must control TWO check points simultaneously for a few seconds as opposed to multiple check points at any given time. Added to the modes is Onslaught, which involves controling nodes until the opposing team's core is exposed. Both Assault and Onslaught now utilize huge environments and...VEHICLES. Removed is the option to have four teams at once (R/B/G/Y) in TDM and DOM. From the obvious graphical enhancement, which has aged quite well, to the varied gameplay, UT2004 delivers.While Unreal Tournament 99/GOTY is my all-time fave FPS, UT2004 slides in right behind it for some damn good reasons.For those wondering where UT2003 went: it's all in UT2004, minus some parts that put fans off. 												DISCLAIMER: If anyone notices I left out UT2003 completely, there's a point to that, and that point is likely parallel to why it only took a single year for another UT to come out.What can I say about this game? The Steam hours say nothing about how much time I've actually put into this game. I first bought it a day after it was released in Canada (That would be about 4 weeks after it was released in the US, based on exchange rates at the time), which would have been when I was 15 or 16 years old. I'm nearly 27 now, and I still hold many fond memories with this game, and will continue to make great memories. It doesn't often see a lot of replay, but the once or twice a year I do jump back into it, I stick to it for at LEAST a week before moving on. That says a lot for an 11 year old game. A lot of other games that age I just can't jump back into because it's just too outdated for me. That, or I've grown up enough to realize that the game actually sucks balls.UT2004 is an FPS, and like the name says, you're in a Tournament setting. You get points for "frags" (kills), capturing flags, holding positions, or whatever else depending on game type. The game is won when either team, or individual player in Deathmatch, reaches a certain goal parameter set by the campaign, yourself in Instant Action, or the Servermaster in Multiplayer. For example, in a Team Deathmatch game, the goal is always going to be the team with the most points collectively. This can be either a set limit, or it can be a timer countdown in which the team with the most frags at the end of the timer wins. The best part of this game, though, is HOW you get your frags. Even in the vanilla game, there are at least a dozen weapons to choose from. For the most part, these weapons are ranged, but there are one or two melee weapons (Who wants to use those, though?). I don't want to spoil the fun for those who are new to the game, so I'll tell you about my favourite: The flak cannon. This weapon was in the original Unreal Tournament, as well, and in it's return, it's packing a meaner punch. Here's what it does: The primary fire throws a dozen or more slugs of white-hot shrapnel at fast speed, ripping your oponent to shreds. Use this fire up close, and like a shotgun, you're bound to make it messy. The secondary fire is more of a mortar, in which the shrapnel is launched still encased, and then explodes into shrapnel on impact. Imagine taking that out in Call of Duty. I have to be super honest, I've never actually fully completed the actual TOURNAMENT (The "campaign" of the game), but I was never really looking for that when I bought the game. I had spent the previous five years playing Unreal Tournament, and 99.2% of that time was playing Practice Sessions, or in the case of UT2004, Instant Action. This is, in my opinion, the Brains of the game. Instant Action is where all the experimentation unfolded. Anything that you downloaded or created yourself was first tested in Instant Action, where it was put to the test with or against computer AI bots. The bots in this game are incredibily intelligent, and also very customizable. To find out more, and there's a LOT more about Instant Action, play the game and experiment yourself. It won't ever get old.When it comes to modability, that's where UT is the most memorable. You get the basic package, which is amazing on it's own and has hundreds of hours of gameplay, but then you also get FULL modability of the game. They even include a full UTEditor where ANYONE can jump in and make maps, good or bad, mods, skins, sounds, graphics, textures, ANYTHING. It's one of the most awesome things I've seen when it comes to a game. And then those who aren't so good with game editing could easily just check community hubs and sites for content. This was what DLC was before it was corporatized and had a price slapped on it for good measure. This is how it still SHOULD be, and I'm glad Steam came up with the workshop. I'm happy there are still a lot of good developers who provide open modability, as well. I just don't see it in this scope anymore. UTEditor was relatively simple (For those who are into it) and basically right there for you to curiously click on and figure out. To put it in perspective, I was creating maps and doing minor mods to UT99 when I was 12. That's about all I can muster for UT2004 right now. There's WAY too much to really rave about, and I don't want to talk circles around anyone. HIGHLY recommend this game. 9.5/10

												Played the Unreal series since 99. No moddern FPS can even compare to this: the Michelangelo of games. At the time, I'd also played Quake, Doom, and CS. But Unreal....oh my, Unreal. My first true love. She snuffed out all others like candles in the rain.Every gamer has that one game that just consumes them. Their pulse quickens and their eyes plaster to the screen, your very soul trapped in an enigma of endless time. Years pass as you watch you life fly by at 60 HZ. Your wrists build strong lasting muscle and hardened tendons from hammering on the WASD keys for hours on end. Your index and middle fingers become your future wifes dream toys as you hone your dexterity with years of mousebutton rappid firing. Your heart races as you shotgun dance with your enemies states and countries apart.This game....This game needs no introduction. It's name is simple and rightfully fitting: Unreal.In it's prime, there were thousands of servers on Game Spy. Close your eyes and point, you'd find one packed with dozens of players from all over the globe. My personal favorite was Instagib (one shot kills). CTF, or TDM. I played in a clan that utilized a player built map system called "giant maps". They were maps that looked like your living room, kitchen, dining room, dorm room, bathroom, etc... but you were the size of a penny. 20 guys buzzing around looking like red or blue dots againt a refridgerator or television. "BigPapa290" is strafing on the floor by the door stop, dodging lasers from an onslaught of enemies flying over the cookie jar. Your clan noob "SparklesTheElephant" is straight walking along the bathroom tiles, still figuring out the controls and somehow lands some lucky shot on your enemies veteran "X-L4X69" who's stalking him from the toilet paper dispenser. "DarkCarnage49" is camped up on the shelf by the fabric softener sniping guys off by the furnace pilot light, but "DeepDishPizza" teleports up from the floor in some crazy zig-zag pattern and an epic battle ensues as they jump and double jump and spin back and fourth until one lands a shot. Then, somehow you've found your way into the clothes dryer drum where there is no wall and everywhere is a mirror. There's no telling which way is out. "HabaneroFarts" has also stumbled upon this trap! Son of a B****! In a fury, you start firing at ghosts. Did I hit him? No, that was his reflection. Why isn't he dead?! How the F*** do I get out of this hell!So you just stand still, hopefully he can just end your misery and you can just die and spawn in the kitty litter box like you were hoping for to begin with.GREAT SCOTT! the memories :)I really doubt you could find games in Unreal that are like this today, but nevertheless, all other game modes are just as fun. This game, is one of 2 game that gets my full 10/10. It consumed my life, man. And I loved every minute of it.

												This is what a competitve shooter should be. A great game at high level skill but simple enough for casual players to join in. The surviving game modes currently are Deathmatch, CTF, and Onslaught. Onslaught is a good start for players, it does not requrie as much attention as CTF or Deathmatch; it's comparable to Titan mode in BF2142 where you have to destroy the other team's main point. There are a large ammount of weapons in this game, each with there own unique use. Most guns have a secondary fire, ifnot they use a zoom function.The movement system is something that will be missed in FPS games. You have your simple Jumps and Double jumps, but then you have dodges and wall dodges. They're like a far reaching side jump, so when your about to get hit you can quickly move off to side into safety (or impending danger) faster than you would have jumping. Since you are unable to rocket jump, shield guns are used as a subsitute. The shield gun's primary can be charged up to deal a damaging wave of force in front of you to kill people who get to close or push up just a bit higher. The longer the charge the higher you can go up, but the more you get hurt.The game is pretty much dead but if you have friends i absolutley reccomend this game, it's an experience you won't get from other shooters made today (mabey other the Quake, and Warsow)

												Every game comes with its positives and negatives. That being said, I think this game is one of the greatest games made to date! I absolutely love it! Epic Games and their engine really did create what I'd consider a masterpiece that is UT2k4. Originally, I got introduced to the Unreal series through the predecessor UT2k3 when I was just a little kid and I almost instantly fell in love with the game. My family was fairly poor at the time, so they could never afford to buy me the game, so I had to get a pirated copy to play. Once 2k4 came out, I loved the even greater variety of game modes that it had to offer as well as the old game modes that were only offered in UT99 at the time. As soon as I started working and made a steam account, I bought Unreal Tournament 2004 because I really do think it's well worth its price. Heck, I even bought it for a few of my close friends for them to play too just because the Unreal series NEEDS to be known, or at least I think it should be. I'll start out with the positives and the things I love about this game.Positives:- Multiple multiplayer game modes- Very different difficulty levels of AI's that do test your skill well, or can help you learn easily- Generally strong, polite, dedicated community (I've met moderators of maps that still hang around ever since the game launched!)- Immersive and very well balanced gameplay- Fast paced- Challenging (In all honesty, I think this game truly tests your weapon handling skills in terms of shooter games)- Fun community game mods and a very well done game editing kit- Competitive- Satisfying gameplay- Many gaming and option features- Character design is fresh and different, many maps to play on, and large gun variety (as well as some sweet vehicles too!)Negatives:- Arena shooters aren't as popular as they used to be- Graphics are outdated (Who cares?)- The rare but occasional hackerHonestly, for me, the negatives don't even hold a candle to the overall game and my rating for it is an easy 10/10That being said, if you want to test your shooting, dodging, reaction time and/or any other skills I highly recommend this game!

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												Temos aqui o terceiro (em ordem cronológica) título da série Unreal lançado no Steam. Lançado em 2004 e que teve o Unreal Engine 2.5 como base. Um FPS frenético onde tiros de metralhadoras, foguetes, plasma e ogivas nucleares vão garantir que você não saia vivo. Agora temos a presença de veículos, mais classes e novos modos de jogo para garantir a diversão por muitas e muitas horas.Avaliação:Classes/Raças: 9/10Temos poucas opções de customização de personagens, nada além de opções de rosto e cor das vestimentas, porém porém isso é mais que suficiente pois na maioria das vezes os corpos simplesmente explodem no meio da partida. Apesar disso, temos cerca de 11 raças para escolher. Não faz muita diferença, pois o importante é destruir o adversário antes que ele te destrua.Modos de jogo: 10/10Unreal Tournament 2004 traz diversos modos de jogo. Muitas horas garantidas e muita variedade para todos os gostos. Estes são alguns dos modos de jogo disponíveis:  -Onslaught: Neste modo de jogo a grande jogada é o uso de veículos, e você precisa destruir todas as bases inimigas para capturá-las em link, todas elas espalhadas em um mapa enorme. Capture todas as bases para ter acesso ao Power Core da equipe inimiga, e destruí-lo. Há grandes conflitos concentrados em bases-chave.  -Bombing Run: Uma espécie de futebol assassino. Você tem que pegar a bola que está no meio do mapa e atirá-la no arco (gol) inimigo. Arremessando a bola você faz 3 pontos, pulando junto com ela você faz 7 pontos. A bola pode ser passada aos aliados, e é derrubada se você for morto.  -Capture the Flag: Este clássico ainda está presente. Faça pontos capturando a bandeira inimiga e levando-a até a sua.  -Double Domination: Seu time faz pontos ao capturar os 2 pontos de controle e mantê-los por 10 segundos. Cada ponto fica em um lado do mapa.  -Mutant: Uma partida Deathmatch comum, e o primeiro a morrer se torna o "mutant". Este jogador recebe munição ilimitada, camuflagem e super-velocidade, mas perde saúde com o tempo. Quando o "mutant" é morto, os poderes dele passam para quem o matou.Música: 9/10A trilha sonora do jogo é interessante, se diferencia um pouco do estilo das músicas de seu antecessor, mas continua sendo bem "animada". Ideal para um jogo frenético como este.Gráficos: 10/10Belos gráficos, muito melhorados se comparados ao Unreal Tournament anterior, agora temos mapas em vastas florestas, cavernas subterrâneas, naves espaciais, mapas submersos e até mesmo do lado de fora de naves no espaço!Controles: 10/10Os mesmos controles de um FPS comum. Algo que pode ser difícil no começo é o sistema de esquiva (apertar duas vezes rapidamente para alguma direção faz seu personagem "desviar" para aquele lado. O que também pode fazer um novo jogador se confundir são os atalhos para as armas, pois temos um total de 19 armas!Arsenal: 10/10Ah, o arsenal de UT2004 continua sendo letal e variado. Dentre as mais interessantes temos:O Translocador, que te permite atirar um disco em qualquer lugar do mapa e se teletransportar para o local onde o disco está;O Bio Rifle, que atira placas de lixo tóxico que grudam nas paredes e na superfície da água;A Link Gun, um rifle que atira rajadas de plasma quente ou uma rajada contínua do mesmo;O Flak Cannon, uma arma que atira estilhaços quente de metal nos inimigos, que ricocheteiam nas paredes;O Rocket Launcher, dispensa comentários, lançador de foguetes que também pode lançá-los em forma de granadas temporizadas. É possível soltar até 3 foguetes ao mesmo tempo;Redeemer, a arma mais poderosa do jogo. Lança uma ogiva nuclear com imensa área de impacto, o que garante diversos Multi-Kills. No tiro secundário, é possível controlar a ogiva com uma câmera. Apesar do poder de fogo, a Redeemer só pode carregar 1 ogiva por vez.Servidores: 8/10Temos diversos servidores com a grande maioria dos modos de jogo disponíveis ao redor do mundo, sendo assim o lag pode ser algo a atrapalhar, ainda mais num jogo com ritmo frenético como este. Apesar disso, o Single Player ainda pode ser um grande desafio nos modos de dificuldade mais avançados.Nota final: 9.4/10A série Unreal Tournament foi (e ainda é) um dos grandes pilares dos FPS, ao lado de jogos como Quake e Counter-Strike. É um FPS especialmente interessante para se jogar, pois proporciona uma experiência bem diferente da que outros jogos de tiro podem te dar. Vale muito a pena.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Arguably the best of the Unreal Tournament games, which seem to follow a popularity trend similar to that of the Godfather... Taken with Unreal Tournament 3, we can see the sad consequences of a gaming industry that increasingly tries to mimic the film industry (is there a real difference anymore?), though the evidence for that claim is a little more implicit between these two titles... The later has fewer maps: Unreal Tournament 2004 has 106 maps (http://liandri.beyondunreal.com/Unreal_Tournament_2004#Maps) compared to the 47 that shipped with Unreal Tournament 3 (http://forums.epicgames.com/threads/579659-Full-UT3-Map-list)One only needs a brain to realise this is less than half. Furthermore, UT3 spreads these maps over 8 game types compared to 10 in UT2004. Why then did UT3 Cost $60 when new, and UT2004 cost $40 despite having only 3 years between release dates? The obvious answer is, it looks better. Many more people are needed to create a new Engine than are needed to create new maps; many more people mean many more salaries to pay whilst maintaining agreeable profits.Why should the gamer settle for less and pay more? The argument that better graphics make up for the defecit can easily be exploded by taking it to its logical conclusion: Would one pay a very large amount, say $100 or more, for a photorealistic game that lasted only several hours? If the answer to that is yes, it in turn begs the question: Why not buy a film?Of course, very little can be done about this trend in practice; big developers will continue to develop, with teams of thousands, games that look fantastic and gross multi-million figures. These games will be short and expensive. These games will have neither pretension nor surplus content (except that that must be brought later). This should not manifest as defeatism however, and least of all complacency.  To undermine this trend, at least in part, one can: Support indie developers by purchasing their games, and being more vocal about them, not pre-order games that promise in advance to be lack-lustre, not pay double the retail price for a bas relief tin and a pamphlet; I am talking here of Legendary Editions and so on (What is legendary about a metal case, art book and a making of... DVD?), be dubious of games released in a yearly fashion, or jack it in all together and find a new hobby.In any case, UT2004 remains a great game in its own right. The volume of content ensures many unique experiences by definition, and the game still has a strong online aspect to be enjoyed. It is fun in the sadistic way that shooting things is, and it sets itself too few pretensions to have any serious flaws. It discarded very little from the original title and updated the graphics to the standard of the time, and it did this without skimping on the things that make a game a game, namely characters, levels and modes, showing yes- it can be done, so yes- I recommend it.

												Seven years since the release of Unreal Tournament 2004, and it still stands as a paragon of the FPS genre.  Gameplay is fast and furious, but death is seldom instant, a feat rarely accomplished in today's world of a-bullet-scratched-me-take-cover health regen games.  Health and shields are static, restored only by pickups.  Ammo and weapons must be picked up and are not granted with perks.  Everything from vehicles to weapons to ammo is out in the field and just waiting to be grabbed.  And there is a great variety. UT2004 features instant-hit weapons, slow moving projectiles with fierce power, inaccurate but fierce automatic weapons, continuous-stream energy weapons, sniper rifles, sticky grenade launchers, and even moving, intelligent mines that can be redirected by the player with a laser.It's colorful, enjoyeable, open to modding, and perhaps the single best shooter of the last decade, even if it wasn't the most influential.

												Even after all these years, UT04 not only holds up both in terms of gameplay, but is actually better than most current offerings. There are 2 main reasons for this: Simple but timeless gameplay, and massive amounts of content. Games like this remind us all of the sad state of the current games industry. This game was released in a era where people expected their games to have content. There was no DLC. And oh boy, does this game have meat on it's bones. Yes it does, with huge amounts of maps, many different game modes, and even a single player tournament mode where you put together a team and fight other teams thus giving a sense of progression in what would otherwise be just a simple arena shooter.  The graphics also actually hold up pretty well. This is largely because the graphic style is a bit cartoonish and very colorful, and thus it doesn't fall into the trap of "not looking realistic anymore" like so many other games do.For 15 bucks, there is no reason not to recommend this game. 10/10.

												Unreal Tournament '99 was one of the first serious FPS games I played. I'd played good ones before, like DN3D, and Doom and stuff, but then came this, THIS game, and it blew me away. Then I played Unreal, as I recall. I played that afterwards, I don't really know how I missed it.Anyway. That was it. I was a huge fan of UT from then on. It was great fun with friends and family.Then UT 2003 came out, and that, that was an awesome game. I loved it. I loved it... but I actually preferred '99. I don't really remember why. I still played the hell out of UT 2003 though. Then, we got 2004. Which was so awesome I instantly switched to it and never really looked back (until now, really, I still love '99 because 2004 doesn't really capture the same spirit that '99 had).UT 2004 however is unbelievably fantastic. When it comes to turbo-classic FPS games, this one should be up there with Quake, Doom, Duke Nukem, Daikatana (pfft), whatever. It's considered by many to be the grand champion of the UT series, which is still going strong today (sort of).I, for one, am super hyped for the UT '99 remake, or whatever it is that Epic Games are doing. But until then, UT 2004. It's got mods, it's still being played, it's great. Get it.
